description: A magazine built for the survivor's .223 assault rifle.  Although well-made, it does not fit STANAG specifications, and still falls short of the real deal in terms of reliability.
A magazine built for the survivor's 7.62x39 assault rifle.  A rough simplification of the AKM magazine pattern, it's still a bit short of the originals legendary reliability.
A magazine built for the survivor's .308 battle rifle.  While well-made, it won't hold up as well as factory designs, and isn't standardized to fit common production models.
A magazine built for the survivor's 7.62x54 battle rifle.  Vaguely based off the magazine design used by the SVT-40, it's well-made but not ideal, and is incompatible with any production firearm.
A magazine built for the survivor's full auto shotgun.  A well-made simplication of the Saiga 12's variant of the AK pattern, it still won't fit to factory specifications.
A magazine built for the survivor's 9mm SMG.  Uses a similar simplification as seen by handmade magazines for the STEN submachine gun, gaining some reliability at the cost of compatibility.
A magazine built for the survivor's .45 SMG.  A .45 ACP conversion of a further-simplified STEN pattern, it's decently-made but not as reliable as factory-made designs.
A magazine built for the survivor's .22 SMG.  Although well-made, it isn't as reliable as factory designs, and isn't compatible with any production firearm.
An ammo belt for the survivor's .223 LMG, using canvas and steel wire to form non-disintegrating links.  Not as reliable as factory-made ammunition belts, and more awkward to reload too.
An ammo belt for the survivor's 7.62x39 LMG, using canvas and steel wire to form non-disintegrating links.  Not as reliable as factory-made ammunition belts, and more awkward to reload too.
An ammo belt for the survivor's .308 GPMG, using canvas and steel wire to form non-disintegrating links.  Not as reliable as factory-made ammunition belts, and more awkward to reload too.
An ammo belt for the survivor's 7.62x54 GPMG, using canvas and steel wire to form non-disintegrating links.  Not as reliable as factory-made ammunition belts, and more awkward to reload too.

This is a homemade power cell made from household batteries along with a series of capacitors, designed to translate mechanical force into enough voltage to more efficiently power a survivor's crank rifle.  Bulkier, less reliable, it's a wonder this thing isn't an electrocution hazard.
